Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2009 01:42PM ReneeJean wrote: I am so fortunate.  I had very little post-op pain with my bmx  with snb and alloderm with TE's placed.  I was on a morphine PCA which I never maxed out in the 24hours I had it.  I was awake, alert and very comfortable by the time I was in my room and stayed that way.  When they d/c the Morphine, I had a choice of norco or motrin....I used the motrin and got up and showered.  The motrin was fine.   At bedtime that night and for the next 3 nights, I took norco and 5mg of valium just to make sure I was able to sleep.  But overall, from 24hr post-op my discomfort was handled easily with motrin or aleve and tylenol.   No one should have post op pain greater than 3-4/10, ever.   That is poor patient management and delays healing.  I am appalled that many doctors/surgeons still handle pain management in this manner.   I am so sorry many of you have had to endure this kind of treatment.   I hope that someday all physicians will enter the 21st century, read the evidence based studies on pain and handle it as has been recommended!  Hugs to all of you.
Posts.Title: Pain medicine for mastectomy--survey tracyanne tracyanne

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2009 11:52AM ReneeJean wrote: I had a Bart PowerPort placed this morning.  Met the radiologist prior to going into the procedure and he explained what he was going to do.  I probably didn't get much 'up front' counseling/teaching/explanation as I am a RN that deals with ports so they assumed I knew what I needed to know (which overall I did).  I didn't have a choice where it was placed. It needed to be on my right side as my cancer and SNB were on the left.  My TE's are very high (I have a wide but short chest) so he placed it in the only place he could.   It will be very visible in any type of v-neck or scoop neck shirt...oh well....it will be gone before summer and the scar will fade.  I am just vain enough to be thankful all this is happening to me as winter approaches---the hats, wigs, scarves, clothing to cover up with, etc......much better than hot humid summer where I tend to wear as few clothes as I can get decently by with<g>
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2009 12:44AM ReneeJean wrote: It was a very hard decision for me.  I had a hard time justifying removing a healthy breast that had no issues.  But my plastic surgeon finally said the magic words--"you are young.   Are you willing to deal with this again in 10 or 12 years?  Can you do this again emotionally?".     Those were the questions that were rolling around in my head since initial diagnosis, but I just wasn't ready to face them.  I made the decision right then to only do this ONCE.....and not have to deal with mammos every 6months with nervous radiologists that would send me for diagnostic mammos and biopsies every time something looked even slightly weird.   And honestly, when talking with my Breast Surgeon later that day, she told me that she had NEVER had anyone come to her and say they regretted having a bilateral, but had many woman come back a year or two later to have the 'healthy' breast removed and expressed regret they hadn't done it at the same time as original surgery!  I am 10 days post op bilateral mx with sentinal node biopsy and TEs placed with 150ml fill....no regrets....I am feeling pretty good, no real pain, just fatigue.  Yes, I regret that I had to lose my breasts, but I am going to live for a very long time with very perky boobies after my recon!!!  LOL. It is a very personal decision and not easy for some of us to make.  I hate surgery and I hate being ill...and I am very healthy....so I wanted the easiest and fastest treatment and recovery....but then I had to weigh that against my future.  For me, I made the right choice.
Posts.Title: What made you decide . . . Mantra Mantra

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2009 09:46PM ReneeJean wrote: Thanks for the welcome ladies....It is encouraging to see and hear your stories.  I am sitting here in the living room with a very unattractive knit cap on my bald head because it is warm and soft.  In 11 days I have come to this point---warm and soft<g>.  Oh well, I can't wait to be one of the ladies encouraging everyone with my hair growth...until then, I will live vicariously through you ladies!!   Prayers for hair growth for each of you.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2009 08:48AM ReneeJean wrote: Chelev, You look beautiful!  Gives me hope.  The hair thing really dropped me to my knees...much harder than the mastectomy.  Afterall, my boob had cancer, it had to go.  My hair was an innocent bystander!  I had my head shaved on day 15 after treatment #1 and I cried for hours and hours and hours.  But amazingly enough, I did find the gumption to put on my big girl panties and get over it....I actually wore a scarf to chemo this week instead of a wig.  I figure in another week or two I will be wearing scarves to work too<g>.  I doubt I will ever be topless other than in bed...but we shall see.  I just want January to be here so my chemo is done and I can concentrate on growing hair......boobless and hairless is not right!!!  My exchange surgery will be in March...so by June I am counting on hair and foobs!  Love the comment about glad going through the hairless stage in summer...I feel just the opposite.  I am so grateful to be going through this in winter...easier to cover up and not be so uncomfortable. I cannot imagine wearing a wig in the heat and humidity.  I have the advantage of warm scarves and hats for the winter...in the summer, you can only take off so much<g>.  Heck, it doesn't matter what time of year this happens, IT SUCKS!  But this too shall pass...LOL
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2009 09:58PM ReneeJean wrote: As already remarked...interesting that we are all stage 1 but such different paths many of us have traveled. I was diagnosed on 7/7, sent for an MRI where they found a 'sattelite' lesion ruling out a lumpectomy for me.  Bil mx on 8/25 with TE's placed.  I have had 3 fills with one to go.  My exchange is scheduled for March 5th.  There is light at the end of this tunnel.  My biggest surprise was chemo.  I had clean margins and no lymph node involvement...  Little did I know!  Today I finished 3 out of a planned 6 tx of C/T.   So far so good.  Losing my hair was a bitch (can I say that?) but I am handling the SE of the chemo pretty well.  I am 45 with no other health conditions so that is in favor.  I went back to work after my first chemo tx, 7 weeks after surgery.  I work a reduced schedule on chemo weeks but love being able to work--it makes the time go by faster. This is not a fun journey, but it is one we will survive and come out the other side.  That is my prayer and beleif!  Hugs to all.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2009 09:54PM ReneeJean wrote: I am on TC, had round #2 last week.  I received my seasonal flu shot prior to beginning treatment.  I always get a seasonal flu shot--had influenza when I was 22 and that was the sickest I have ever been.   I also work in a Pediatric ER.  I will NOT be getting H1N1 vaccination.  Personal choice and my cancer has nothing to do with my decision.   Surprisingly, many of my co-workers feel the same as our H1N1 vaccine is sitting unused.......
Posts.Title: H1N1 Poll--ALL STAGES WELCOME! badboob67 wildgardener

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2009 07:38PM ReneeJean wrote: Well, my period started on the 25th of September, right on schedule.  My first TC treatment was the 30th.....my second TC was on the 21st...and I am still on my period.  I have been heavy flow EVERY SINGLE DAY FOR A MONTH!  Not normal for me.  I had a pelvic/vaginal U/S prior to surgery so we know everything is okay down there.....just my ovaries going into hyperdrive or something?   My oncologist wants me to see my gyn this week if it doesn't stop so we can discuss an endo ablation prior to treatment #3.  I am anemic and this doesn't help, so they are concerned.
Posts.Title: Vaginal bleeding after first round of chemo anyone? Piffken buttonsmachine

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2009 02:01PM ReneeJean wrote: I am a night shift RN just diagnosed with IDC!   I too have seen the information that is linking night shift workers to an increased risk of cancers.  Probably the constant stress we are under by not sleeping enough and trying to live a normal life when we are not working nights!!  Unfortunately I have a broad base of information on BC due to past experience---I have 2 friends that have died of this horrid disease and one that is currently in year 4 of being 'cancer free'.  I am very fortunate to have a great management team that is doing whatever they can to accomodate my illness.  Hopefully I will be able to keep working as I am hoping for lumpectomy/radiation, but should I need chemo, we will deal with that (I work in a Pedi ER).  My surgeon is great and I am scheduled for an MRI this week to confirm the size of my tumor.    I have found that so far being a nurse has been helpful.  The radiologist and all the nurses invovled in my diagnosis and biopsy were more forthcoming due to me being a Nurse and my oncologist was very frank and able to talk to me without having to explain every little thing.   And I DON'T like being a patient at all!!!!
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2009 04:58PM ReneeJean wrote: Yes, our personalities are that of being 'superwoman' and head caretaker that lead us to nursing.  Add to that I am the typical ED nurse---short attention span and going 1000 miles an hour--anything less makes me crazy!  So, no, I am not a good patient nor do I possess patience!  I have thought that maybe one of the lessons I am going to learn from this proccess is PATIENCE...but I am not counting on it.  I had my MRI the other day and had to tell myself the entire time that if I freaked out I would just have to do it again.  I literally had a running commentary in my head telling myself to slow down my breathing and not think about the claustrophobic feelings I was having!   I am a baby...but I got through it.  One step at a time is how we manage this disease. I began to tell co-workers this week.  Everyone is great.  It is hard to see the fear/care/loss of words when they hear (and why I considered not telling anyone).   As with most night shifts, we are a pretty close group and it is nice to have their support.  I know I have lots of prayers going up on my behalf due to these wonderful folks.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10
